artistabernard: Hello Greta, I am Jorge Bernard visual artist from Argentina. I live in Tierra del Fuego. I am writing to you because I know your commitment to the environment and the policies aimed at stopping climate change on Earth. The action is URGENT. I want to invite you to join our artistic exhibition project called “Burning House”. It refers to our house as a body, habitat house and planet on which we live, which is literally on fire. The initiative arises from us, a group of artists and dreamers, to put on the table the environmental problems that put us in check as responsible inhabitants of this planet. The exhibition will be of all branches of art: painting, drawing, mural, photography, animation, theater, music, printmaking, comics, literature, cinema, etc. It also includes talks and workshops on conscious and vegan eating. A series of conferences given by scientists from CADIC-CONICET are also planned. I invite you to join in the way you can and want, it can be a work of art, either in physical form or via email, or a video message addressed to the people of the South Pole, a place so sensitive to global warming. I hope it is to your liking and you want to collaborate with us. I send you a big greeting Jorge Bernard

anabundanceofsheep: “Fundamental equal rights, not congratulations or celebrations” - Can we talk about how it’s now politically incorrect to celebrate civil rights? The misconception that celebrating civil rights does nothing to help alienates ordinary people and those less inclined to activism. “If I can’t celebrate the contributions of women on International Women’s Day”, people wind up thinking, “what CAN I do to fight misogyny?” Yes, we need action greater than celebrating women in order to achieve equal rights. But saying celebration of women is unwanted drives away people who you would rather have listen to you. For every social justice cause, we must look toward what we still need to accomplish, but also celebrate how far we’ve already come. You want your audience to grow, Greta. We all want your audience to grow. By criticizing the efforts of millions of well-meaning people across the world, you are convincing nobody, and turning away all but the most committed.
